questions.text: Features of restrictive lung disease are: What will be the pattern seen on pulmonary function test in a young boy presenting to the clinic with c/o breathlessness, tachypnea, clear chest and congenital kyphoscoliosis:
questions.correct_answer: D. FEV1/FVC increases and compliance decreases
questions.explanation:
Solution:

FEV1/FVC increases and compliance decreases People with restrictive lung disease cannot fully fill their lungs with air. Their lungs are restricted from fully expanding. Restrictive lung disease most often results from a condition causing stiffness in the lungs themselves. In other cases, stiffness of the chest wall, weak muscles, or damaged nerves may cause restriction in lung expansion. Some conditions causing restrictive lung disease are: Interstitial lung disease , such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis Sarcoidosis , an autoimmune disease Obesity , including obesity hypoventilation syndrome Scoliosis Neuromuscular disease, such as muscular dystrophy or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

Highyeild:

Basic Concept: During an obstruction in airways, there is a decrease in expiratory flow which becomes more pronounced when expiration is more forceful. Hallmark is a decrease in expiratory flow rates. FEV1 is markedly reduced and FVC is mildly reduced so the ratio of FEV1 / FVC is highly reduced. Diffusion capacity is normal except in emphysema where it is reduced. Important Points Causes of Obstructive airway diseases: Asthma COPD Bronchiectasis Cystic Fibrosis Bronchiolitis Restrictive Pattern

FEV1/FVC decreases and compliance increases are seen in obstructive lung diseases especially emphysema and not in a restrictive pattern

Hallmark is a decrease in TLC and VC (Reduce lung volume). FEV1 is mildly reduced but FVC is highly reduced so the ratio of FEV1 / FVC is normal or increased. Diffusion capacity is reduced. questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a 50-pack-year history of smoking comes to his doctor's office complaining of shortness of breath. While sitting, the patient is leaning forward and breathing with his lips pursed. Auscultation of his lungs reveals a prolonged expiratory phase. Which of the following statements describes gas exchange in his lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: Gas exchange does not differ from that in a healthy individual

options.label: B
options.text: Gas exchange will increase with an increase in blood flow

options.label: C
options.text: The diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide is increased

options.label: D
options.text: There is a decreased surface area for gas exchange

questions.correct_answer: D. There is a decreased surface area for gas exchange
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There is a decreased surface area for gas exchange This patient with shortness of breath, a long smoking history, and a prolonged expiratory time is suffering from emphysema, an obstructive lung disease in which alveoli are destroyed . This decreases the surface area for gas exchange and illustrates diffusion-limited exchange.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. is not correct. The destruction of alveoli and other gas-exchanging air spaces leads to diffusion-limited gas exchange that is not apparent in healthy individuals. Option: B. is not correct. An increase in blood flow will not increase gas exchange in emphysema because the limiting factor in gas exchange is the decreased surface area for exchange, not blood flow. Option: C. is not correct. The diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide will decrease because the surface area for gas exchange decreases in emphysema.

options.label: D
options.text: A - pulmonary fibrosis, B - emphysema, C - normal

questions.correct_answer: B. A - emphysema, B - normal, C - pulmonary fibrosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A - emphysema, B - normal, C - pulmonary fibrosis Emphysema is a degenerative and potentially fatal pulmonary disease that is characterized by a loss of lung elasticity and replacement of alveoli with large air sacs. So lung volume increases for the same amount of transpulmonary pressure. Another point about inspiration in emphysema is that the lung attains a completely filled position, much earlier. This is because, loss of elasticity prevents full expansion of the lung, or airway restriction, during breathing. Fibrosis causes an increase in the stiffness of the lung such that only a very little amount of air can enter inside, and that too with a good amount of transpulmonary pressure.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhale slowly and deeply - hold - exhale through pursed lips This instrument is an incentive spirometer.

Highyeild:

After surgery, it may be difficult to breathe as you normally do. You may notice your breathing changes to small, shallow breaths. This can cause fluid and mucus to build up in your lungs, increasing your risk for respiratory system complications. An incentive spirometer is a hand-held breathing exercise device to help you breathe deeply. Taking deep breaths allows air to inflate your lungs, opening your airways to prevent fluid and mucus buildup. Using an incentive spirometer may speed your recovery and lower your risk of lung problems such as pneumonia.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male visited the medicine opd for a checkup. He has a quiet chest with diffusely decreased breath sounds and a history of 40 pack years of smoking. The physician suspected emphysema and sent the patient for spirometry. The attendant asked about the test of curiosity and so the doctor explained to them the nature and uses of this test. A normal spirogram is given below, identify A, B, and C.

options.label: A
options.text: A = FORCED VITAL CAPACITY, B = TOTAL LUNG CAPACITY, C = RESIDUAL VOLUME

options.label: B
options.text: A = TOTAL LUNG CAPACITY, B = VITAL CAPACITY, C = RESIDUAL VOLUME

options.label: C
options.text: A = TOTAL LUNG CAPACITY, B = FORCED VITAL CAPACITY, C = INSPIRATORY RESERVE VOLUME

options.label: D
options.text: A = TOTAL LUNG CAPACITY, B = VITAL CAPACITY, C = EXPIRATORY RESERVE VOLUME

questions.correct_answer: D. A = TOTAL LUNG CAPACITY, B = VITAL CAPACITY, C = EXPIRATORY RESERVE VOLUME
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A = TOTAL LUNG CAPACITY, B = VITAL CAPACITY, C = EXPIRATORY RESERVE VOLUME The lung volumes can be measured using spirometry First, normal breathing is measured (tidal volume). Next, the subject takes maximal inspiration and followed this with a maximal expiration. The exhaled volume is called the vital capacity. However, some gas remained in the lung after a maximal expiration; this is the residual volume. The volume of gas in the lung after a normal expiration is the functional residual capacity (FRC) . Certain lung volumes, particularly the FRC , are determined by elastic forces. It is a convenient starting point at which to consider the various lung volumes and their subdivision

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . is an incorrect answer as total lung capacity should be the maximum Option: B. is an incorrect answer as residual volume is the minimum and it is labelled wrong Option: is an incorrect answer as it is expiratory reserve volume and not inspiratory reserve volume

Extraedge:

Lung volumes - Tidal volume: Volume of air inspired or expired during a normal inspiration or expiration Inspiratory reserve volume: The additional volume a subject is capable of inhaling after a normal, quiet inspiration Expiratory reserve volume: The additional volume a subject is capable of exhaling after a normal, quiet expiration. Residual volume: Volume of air remaining in respiratory passages and lungs after the most forceful expiration A 'capacity' usually refers to a measurement comprised of more than one 'volume." Lung capacities- Total lung capacity (TLC): The volume of gas in the lungs after maximal inspiration. Vital capacity (VC): The maximum volume of air that a subject can exhale after maximal inspiration. Functional residual capacity (FRC): The volume remaining in the lungs after expiration during normal, quiet breathing. Inspiratory capacity (IC): The maximum volume that can be inspired after expiration during normal, quiet breathing.

questions.text: While studying various cases for his thesis, a 2nd-year medicine resident noticed that expiratory airflow limitation commonly occurs due to diffuse pulmonary airway disease like asthma. Conversely, extrathoracic airway narrowing like in tracheal adenoma or post-tracheostomy stricture can lead to inspiratory airflow limitation. What could be the possible explanation for this?

options.label: A
options.text: Inspiration is concerned mainly with intrathoracic airways while expiration occurs mainly by extrathoracic airways

options.label: B
options.text: Bernoulli’s effect is responsible for inspiratory airflow limitation.

options.label: C
options.text: Bernoulli’s effect is the main reason for expiratory airflow limitation.

options.label: D
options.text: Obstruction in the case of asthma is fixed while in tracheal stenosis, it is variable.

questions.correct_answer: C. Bernoulli’s effect is the main reason for expiratory airflow limitation.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bernoulli’s effect is the main reason for expiratory airflow limitation. Diseases that narrow the airway lumen at any transmural pressure (e.g., asthma or chronic bronchitis) or that cause excessive airway collapsibility (e.g., tracheomalacia) also reduce maximal expiratory flow. The Bernoulli effect applies during inspiration, but the more negative pleural pressures during inspiration lower the pressure outside of the airways, thereby increasing transmural pressure and promoting airway expansion. (option B)

Highyeild:

Thus, inspiratory airflow limitation seldom occurs due to diffuse pulmonary airway disease. extrathoracic airway narrowing (e.g., due to a tracheal adenoma or post-tracheostomy stricture) can lead to inspiratory airflow limitation (option A) While the individual airways in each successive generation, from most proximal (trachea) to most distal (respiratory bronchioles), are smaller than those of the parent generation, their number increases exponentially such that the summed cross-sectional area of the airways becomes very large toward the lung periphery. Because flow is constant along the airway tree, the velocity of airflow (flow/summed cross-sectional area) is much greater in the central airways than in the peripheral airways. During exhalation, the gas leaving the alveoli must, therefore, gain velocity as it proceeds toward the mouth. The energy required for this “ convective” acceleration is drawn from the component of gas energy manifested as its local pressure, which reduces intraluminal gas pressure, airway transmural pressure, airway size, and flow. This phenomenon is the Bernoulli effect . This is the reason for the flow limit, which is also responsible for the residual volume of the lungs. In the case of diffuse airway diseases like asthma or emphysema, this Bernoulli effect cause increased obstruction midway So asthma is a variable obstruction dynamic obstruction), while tracheal stenosis is a fixed obstruction option D Stenosis causes obstruction in both inspiration and expiration.

Dynamic compression of the airways during the forced expiratory effort is an important determinant of the RV as airway collapse occurs, thus trapping gas in the alveoli. questions.text: The spirometric findings of a patient are given below - Tidal volume - 600 ml Inspiratory reserve volume - 2500 ml Expiratory reserve volume = 2000 ml The volume of air that remains inside conducting zone during ventilation is 200 ml. The forced vital capacity is 2100 ml. The total lung capacity is 5000 ml. respiratory rate is 20 per minute Let's consider a hypothetical situation with this patient, where perfusion of the left lung completely vanishes, and only the right lung is able to perform a gaseous exchange. All other parameters are the same as previously and he is a healthy adult. What will be the approximate alveolar ventilation of this patient under the given hypothetical condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

14 L Alveolar ventilation is the fraction of tidal volume which comes in contact with alveoli during ventilation EXCLUDING physiological dead spaces.

Highyeild:

In this HYPOTHETICAL SITUATION - because perfusion of the left lung is lost - the gaseous exchange will only hamper - no effect on ventilation of the concerned lung ( however it will be in physiological dead space ventilation) The physiological dead space is defined as including anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space components. In normal subjects, the measurement is primarily determined by the contribution of the anatomical dead space, with a small addition from the alveolar dead space attributable to normal ventilation/perfusion heterogeneity. [directly taken from a summary of European respiratory journal] VP heterogenicity here is -ventilation is same, but perfusion wrt ventilation is almost half = VP heterogenicity-V/P/2) =2V/P= heterogenicity is doubled This means physiological dead space can be expected to get doubled. Here alveolar ventilation (tidal volume-physiological dead space) * RR Physiological dead space = anatomical dead space + alveolar (functional) dead space (volume entering alveoli of only left lungs) Dead space = 200+ (600-200)/2 = 400 Alveolar ventilation = (600-400) 20 = 200 20 = 4000 ml = 4 L Alveolar ventilation < the minute ventilation because the last part of each inspiration remains in the conducting airways and does not reach the alveoli. The last part of each expiration remains in the conducting airways and is not expelled from the body. No gas exchange occurs in the conducting airways for anatomic reasons: The walls of the conducting airways are too thick for much diffusion to take place; mixed venous blood does not come into contact with the air: the anatomic dead space. Thus, with each 600-mt, inspiration, only the initial 400 mL of fresh air entering the body reaches the alveoli. With each 600-mL expiration, only the final 400 mL of air exiting the body comes from the alveoli. One 200-mL bolus of fresh air shuttles back and forth between the atmosphere and conducting airways. Another 200-ml bolus of stale air shuttles back and forth between the conducting airways and alveoli.
